_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Valves, safety systems and control safeties

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Jasper Wyman & Son will conduct a prevention program compliance audit in conjunction with the 5-year revision and resubmittal of its Risk Management Plan.  Findings that are identified as a result of this compliance audit will be promptly addressed to determine and document an appropriate corrective actions for each of the findings as required by the regulations.

red as a result of the release, and the incident was reported to the State.  

An incident investigation was conducted in association with the March 2015 release.  As part of the investigation, the belt installation was inspected for possible installation error or other defects.  The belt was installed properly and was not the root cause of the incident. It was determined that the crank shaft experienced a mechanical failure due to age.  A diagnostic evaluation was conducted on similar pieces of equipment to determine if there was a risk of failure on other pieces of equipment.

No other releases of ammonia occurred in the prior five years. 

5. THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Jasper Wyman & Son has developed and implemented an Emergency Response Plan which governs our actions in the event of an emergency, including an ammonia release.  A process release would be detected by ammonia sensors installed in the engine room and freezers one through five.  A process release could also be detected by the employees through odor.  High and low liquid alarms are present on the ammonia storage tanks.  The fire alarm and H2O suppression system are tested/checked quarterly by ADT and Maine Fire.  The ammonia sensors remain tested on a semi-annual basis.  An alarm signal is triggered and would sound and light throughout the facility, and the exhaust system would be activated automatically. 

In the event of a process release, ADT calls the facility (maintenance department), which would in turn contact the Ellsworth Fire Department if any of the following conditions are present:

- Upon investigating the incident, Jasper Wyman & Son determines that the release is severe enough to require response assistance;
- Reportable quantities of ammonia are released; or
- A potential for fire exists (in this case, ADT directly notifies the Fire Department).

The Ellsworth Fire Department is trained and equipped to respond to ammonia releases at Jasper Wyman & Son.

6. PLANNED

a RMP for its covered processes.  The anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems at Jasper Wyman & Son are the only processes that store a substance in greater quantities than the ARPP applicability threshold.

The process is subject to Risk Management Program 3 because it is subject to OSHA-PSM provisions and it is not eligible for Program 1.

3. THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The process is currently designed and maintained in compliance with American National Standards Institute /American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE) guidance, and American Society of Mechanical Engineering (ASME) guidance as documented in Jasper Wyman & Son' PSM Plan.  Process verification takes place through design audits by trained personnel and/or certified consultants.  The schedule of such verifications (PHA) is at least once every five years.

Preventative maintenance (PM) is an active part of Jasper Wyman & Son' daily operations.  PM is performed on a regular schedule in accordance with OSHA-PSM.  Ammonia detection sensors are present at six locations (engine room and freezers one through five) and are tested several times a year.  Relief valves are replaced, inspected, repaired, tested and/or sealed on a five-year schedule.  Differential pressure gages are replaced immediately upon discovery of any damage that may breach the integrity of the compressed ammonia process.

4. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Within the last five years, Jasper Wyman & Son has had only one accident involving compressed ammonia.  No deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, offsite evacuations or sheltering-in-place occurred during this event.  On March 27, 2015, an estimated 300 pounds of ammonia was released from the cold storage CP Booster number two (2) due to a Crank Shaft failure. The plant was shut down and evacuated.  No deaths, injuries, environmental impacts, or off-site evacuations occur

Jasper Wyman & Son Executive Summary Report

1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
It is Jasper Wyman & Son's policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and local laws.  The ammonia refrigeration process at Jasper Wyman & Son (process) has been designed and operates in compliance with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention rule, and applicable State and local codes and regulations. Jasper Wyman & Son has qualified engineering, operations, and maintenance personnel knowledgeable in the safe operation of compressed ammonia systems in direct responsibility of the process.  The process is also designed and operated in compliance with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's Process Safety Management (OSHA-PSM) rule.  

Through its Emergency Response Plan as required under OSHA-PSM, Jasper Wyman & Son has emergency response procedures in place that comply with the Accidental Release Prevention Program (ARPP).

2. FACILITY AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
Jasper Wyman & Son is a food processing facility primarily engaged in the blast freezing of freshly harvested blueberries.  The berries are then stored in a cold storage freezer.  The facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia within two separate systems: 
- Cold Storage Ammonia Refrigeration System: 7,000 pounds (Max. intended inventory)
- York Tunnel Ammonia Refrigeration System: 9,000 pounds (Max. intended inventory)

The Cold Storage System includes compressor equipment, low pressure receivers, high pressure receivers (outdoor), and intercoolers located in the same area of the facility.  The York Tunnel system is isolated from the other system because it is located in a separate area of the facility.

The ARPP applicability threshold for anhydrous ammonia is 10,000 pounds.  As Jasper Wyman & Son' co-located anhydrous ammonia storage capacity could exceed this threshold with maximum operating charge, the facility is subject to the program and is required to prepare
